cause: Fungal infection by Puccinia graminis f. sp. tritici (including virulent races such as Ug99)
symptoms: Red‐brown pustules on stems and leaves; severe infections lead to lodging and major yield loss
cure: Utilize resistant cultivars, apply fungicides preemptively, and practice crop rotation

symptoms: Small orange‐brown pustules scattered on leaves that coalesce and cause premature senescence
cure: Apply fungicides (e.g., triazoles), adopt resistant varieties, and rotate crops

symptoms: Bleached spikelets with pinkish mold formation; grain may be contaminated with mycotoxins
cure: Use resistant cultivars, treat seeds and heads with appropriate fungicides, and implement crop rotation

cause: Fungal infection by Blumeria graminis f. sp. tritici
symptoms: White, powdery growth covering leaves and spikes that reduces photosynthetic area
cure: Apply sulfur‐based or systemic fungicides and improve field air circulation; select resistant lines

symptoms: Diamond-shaped lesions on leaves and neck rot on panicles leading to premature ripening
cure: Employ resistant rice varieties, apply fungicides early, and maintain strict field sanitation

cause: Bacterial infection by Xanthomonas oryzae pv. oryzae
symptoms: Water-soaked lesions that turn yellow and dry out on the leaf margins and midribs
cure: Use resistant cultivars, apply copper-based bactericides, and practice proper field management

symptoms: Lesions on leaf sheaths near the waterline with gradual tissue blighting
cure: Improve field drainage, use balanced fertilization and appropriate fungicide applications

symptoms: Long, elliptical, gray-green lesions with dark margins on maize leaves
cure: Deploy resistant hybrids, apply fungicides when conditions favor the disease, and rotate crops

symptoms: Irregular, rectangular, gray to brown lesions with yellow halos on leaves
cure: Apply targeted fungicides, adopt resistant cultivars, and manage crop residue to reduce inoculum

symptoms: Dark, sunken lesions on leaves, stalks, and ears, leading to ear rot
cure: Use resistant varieties, practice crop rotation, and apply fungicides at early disease onset
